elements.content: Two metal–organic frameworks [Zn2(Tipa)2­(OH)]·​3NO3·​12H2O (FIR-53, FIR denotes Fujian Institute of Research, Tipa = tris­(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­phenyl)­amine)) and [Zn­(Tipa)]·2NO3·​DMF·​4H2O) (FIR-54) with large nanotubular channels were synthesized via Zn­(II) ions coordinate the neutral Tipa ligand. The framework of FIR-53 contains 1D channels along the c axis with a cross section of 18 × 13 Å2. FIR-54 also consists of large channels with the 10.5 × 10.5 Å2 open windows. These porous materials efficiently trap Cr2O7 2– inorganic pollutant ions via the single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) approach. The Cr2O7 2– uptake capacities of FIR-53 and FIR-54 are high to 74.2 and 103 mg/g, respectively. Furthermore, the Cr2O7 2– trapping–releasing process of FIR-53 displays good regeneration. Meaningfully, the structure of FIR-53 after ion exchange can be accurately obtained by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, which further elaborates the SC-SC transformation.
elements.clean_text: Two metal-organic frameworks [Zn2(Tipa)2(OH)]⋅3NO3⋅12H2O (FIR-53, FIR denotes Fujian Institute of Research, Tipa = tris(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)phenyl)amine)) and [Zn(Tipa)]⋅2NO3⋅DMF⋅4H2O) (FIR-54) with large nanotubular channels were synthesized via Zn(II) ions coordinate the neutral Tipa ligand. The framework of FIR-53 contains 1D channels along the c axis with a cross section of 18 × 13 Å2. FIR-54 also consists of large channels with the 10.5 × 10.5 Å2 open windows. These porous materials efficiently trap Cr2O7 2- inorganic pollutant ions via the single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) approach. The Cr2O7 2- uptake capacities of FIR-53 and FIR-54 are high to 74.2 and 103 mg/g, respectively. Furthermore, the Cr2O7 2- trapping-releasing process of FIR-53 displays good regeneration. Meaningfully, the structure of FIR-53 after ion exchange can be accurately obtained by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, which further elaborates the SC-SC transformation.

elements.content: Nowadays, water pollution is a global environmental issue, and considerable research attention has been paid to the removal of pollutants from wastewater. Various techniques have been introduced for the removal of inorganic metal ions, including ion exchange, adsorption, photocatalytic reduction, or degradation. Commonly, ion exchange is regarded as a cost-effective and eco-friendly strategy since it usually offers several advantages in terms of sensitivity, selectivity, and simplicity of operation. Generally, ion exchangers are divided into two categories: inorganic and organic types. Most inorganic ion exchangers, such as zeolites and layered double hydroxides, depend on small pore sizes for ionic exchange, and thus exchange kinetics is slow, as well as adsorption capacity is limited. Although organic exchangers, such as sol–gel adsorbents and polymer resins, are rapid in exchange, they do not have excellent thermal and chemical stability like inorganic counterparts. The development of higher-performance ion exchangers for water treatment is still challenge.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Nowadays, water pollution is a global environmental issue, and considerable research attention has been paid to the removal of pollutants from wastewater. Various techniques have been introduced for the removal of inorganic metal ions, including ion exchange, adsorption, photocatalytic reduction, or degradation. Commonly, ion exchange is regarded as a cost-effective and eco-friendly strategy since it usually offers several advantages in terms of sensitivity, selectivity, and simplicity of operation. Generally, ion exchangers are divided into two categories: inorganic and organic types. Most inorganic ion exchangers, such as zeolites and layered double hydroxides, depend on small pore sizes for ionic exchange, and thus exchange kinetics is slow, as well as adsorption capacity is limited. Although organic exchangers, such as sol-gel adsorbents and polymer resins, are rapid in exchange, they do not have excellent thermal and chemical stability like inorganic counterparts. The development of higher-performance ion exchangers for water treatment is still challenge.

elements.content: As an emerging class of porous materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with high surface areas are built from metal ions or metal-based clusters linked by various organic bridging ligands. The main advantage of MOFs over other microporous materials (e.g., zeolites or activated carbons) resides in the opportunity to control the pore surface properties, such as the precisely porous microenvironment, and tunable channel size. The outstanding characters of MOFs should facilitate more chemical and physical properties, such as a host–guest system, ion exchange, and size-confinement effect for the adsorption of organic dyes. These MOF materials have been expected to play a role as an important platform for the remediation of environmental problems.
elements.clean_text: As an emerging class of porous materials, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with high surface areas are built from metal ions or metal-based clusters linked by various organic bridging ligands. The main advantage of MOFs over other microporous materials (e.g., zeolites or activated carbons) resides in the opportunity to control the pore surface properties, such as the precisely porous microenvironment, and tunable channel size. The outstanding characters of MOFs should facilitate more chemical and physical properties, such as a host-guest system, ion exchange, and size-confinement effect for the adsorption of organic dyes. These MOF materials have been expected to play a role as an important platform for the remediation of environmental problems.

elements.content: It is well-known that many of the metal pollutants as their oxo-hydroxo anionic forms (e.g., pertechnetate (TcO4 –), arsenate (AsO4 3–), selenite (SeO3 2–, etc.) occur in water. One of these priorities, chromate (CrO4 2– or Cr2O7 2–), is rapidly diffusing and a known carcinogen, occurring from metal-plating, leather-tanning, and other industries. So far, to the best of our knowledge, only several cationic MOFs were reported to trap chromate or dichromate via ion exchange. The uptake capacities of chromate or dichromate ions in these MOFs have potential to be improved, and the dichromate trapping processes for theses MOFs are rarely known from a single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) fashion. To gain direct and accurate structural information, the SC-SC fashion is a preferable platform for the host–guest chemistry of adsorption and ion exchange.
elements.clean_text: It is well-known that many of the metal pollutants as their oxo-hydroxo anionic forms (e.g., pertechnetate (TcO4 -), arsenate (AsO4 3-), selenite (SeO3 2-, etc.) occur in water. One of these priorities, chromate (CrO4 2- or Cr2O7 2-), is rapidly diffusing and a known carcinogen, occurring from metal-plating, leather-tanning, and other industries. So far, to the best of our knowledge, only several cationic MOFs were reported to trap chromate or dichromate via ion exchange. The uptake capacities of chromate or dichromate ions in these MOFs have potential to be improved, and the dichromate trapping processes for theses MOFs are rarely known from a single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) fashion. To gain direct and accurate structural information, the SC-SC fashion is a preferable platform for the host-guest chemistry of adsorption and ion exchange.

elements.content: Herein, we report two cationic MOFs with large nanotubular channels, [Zn2(Tipa)2­(OH)]·3NO3·​12H2O (FIR-53, FIR denotes Fujian Institute of Research, Tipa = tris­(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­phenyl)­amine)) and [Zn­(Tipa)]·2NO3·​DMF·​4H2O (FIR-54), which show fast ion exchange and high uptake capacity for Cr2O7 2– through the SC-SC process.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report two cationic MOFs with large nanotubular channels, [Zn2(Tipa)2(OH)]⋅3NO3⋅12H2O (FIR-53, FIR denotes Fujian Institute of Research, Tipa = tris(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)phenyl)amine)) and [Zn(Tipa)]⋅2NO3⋅DMF⋅4H2O (FIR-54), which show fast ion exchange and high uptake capacity for Cr2O7 2- through the SC-SC process.

elements.content: The tris­(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­phenyl)­amine (Tipa) was prepared according to the literature method. All other chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and were used without further purification. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were carried out with a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One spectrophotometer. All powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were recorded on a MiniFlex-II diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with a step size of 0.05°. Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a N2 atmosphere. UV–vis adsorption spectra were collected on a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 spectrophotometer to monitor the exchange progress. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) measurement was performed on an Ultima-2 spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instrumentation

The tris(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)phenyl)amine (Tipa) was prepared according to the literature method. All other chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and were used without further purification. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were carried out with a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One spectrophotometer. All powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were recorded on a MiniFlex-II diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with a step size of 0.05°. Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a N2 atmosphere. UV-vis adsorption spectra were collected on a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 spectrophotometer to monitor the exchange progress. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) measurement was performed on an Ultima-2 spectrometer.

elements.content: Tris­(4-bromo­phenyl)­amine (0.480 g, 1.0 mmol), imidazole (0.41 g, 6.0 mmol), K2CO3 (0.728 g, 6.0 mmol), and CuSO4 (0.01 g, 0.04 mmol) were mixed and heated at 120 °C for 48 h under a nitrogen atmosphere. The mixture was cooled to the room temperature, and was then washed with water. The solids were filtered and dried to give the light pale crude product. Final Tipa sample was recrystallized from this light pale crude product by using water and ethanol as solvent (Yield: 74%).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Tris(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)phenyl)amine (Tipa; Scheme )

Tris(4-bromophenyl)amine (0.480 g, 1.0 mmol), imidazole (0.41 g, 6.0 mmol), K2CO3 (0.728 g, 6.0 mmol), and CuSO4 (0.01 g, 0.04 mmol) were mixed and heated at 120 °C for 48 h under a nitrogen atmosphere. The mixture was cooled to the room temperature, and was then washed with water. The solids were filtered and dried to give the light pale crude product. Final Tipa sample was recrystallized from this light pale crude product by using water and ethanol as solvent (Yield: 74%).

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthesis of Tipa Ligand

elements.content: A mixture of Tipa (0.0225 g, 0.05 mmol), l-proline (0.0115 g, 0.10 mmol), Zn­(NO3)2·​6H2O (0.0560 g, 0.2 mmol), MeOH (8 mL), and NaOH (2 mL, 0.1 M) was heated in a 20 mL scintillation vial at 100 °C for 72 h, followed by cooling to room temperature. The resulting mixture was washed with methanol and water, and colorless block crystals were collected and dried in air (29.2 mg, 73% yield, based on Tipa ligand).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of FIR-53 

A mixture of Tipa (0.0225 g, 0.05 mmol), l-proline (0.0115 g, 0.10 mmol), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0560 g, 0.2 mmol), MeOH (8 mL), and NaOH (2 mL, 0.1 M) was heated in a 20 mL scintillation vial at 100 °C for 72 h, followed by cooling to room temperature. The resulting mixture was washed with methanol and water, and colorless block crystals were collected and dried in air (29.2 mg, 73% yield, based on Tipa ligand).

elements.content: A mixture of Tipa (0.0225 g, 0.05 mmol), l-proline (0.0115 g, 0.10 mmol), Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0560 g, 0.2 mmol), and DMF/MeOH/H2O (5 mL, v:v:v 3:1:1) was placed in a 20 mL scintillation vial at 100 °C for 12 h, followed by cooling to room temperature. The resulting mixture was washed with DMF and water, and colorless block crystals were collected and dried in air (38.4 mg, 64% yield, based on Tipa ligand).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of FIR-54 

A mixture of Tipa (0.0225 g, 0.05 mmol), l-proline (0.0115 g, 0.10 mmol), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0560 g, 0.2 mmol), and DMF/MeOH/H2O (5 mL, v:v:v 3:1:1) was placed in a 20 mL scintillation vial at 100 °C for 12 h, followed by cooling to room temperature. The resulting mixture was washed with DMF and water, and colorless block crystals were collected and dried in air (38.4 mg, 64% yield, based on Tipa ligand).

elements.content: The crystals of as-synthesized FIR-53 (60 mg, 0.05 mmol) were immersed in a 20 mL 2 × 10–3 mol/L solution of K2Cr2O7 and kept for 6 days. After decanting the solution, the resultant orange-yellow crystals were washed thoroughly with deionized water and dried in air.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of FIR-53-Cr2O7  

The crystals of as-synthesized FIR-53 (60 mg, 0.05 mmol) were immersed in a 20 mL 2 × 10-3 mol/L solution of K2Cr2O7 and kept for 6 days. After decanting the solution, the resultant orange-yellow crystals were washed thoroughly with deionized water and dried in air.

elements.content: Suitable single crystals were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Whereafter, single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses were performed on a computer-controlled SuperNova CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λMo–Kα = 0.71073 Å) and Cu Kα radiation (λCu–Kα = 1.54178 Å). The structures were solved using the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 by using the SHELX-97 program package. The SQUEEZE option of PLATON was used to eliminate the contribution of disordered guest molecules to the reflection intensities. The formulas of FIR-53 and FIR-54 were calculated by considering the results of thermogravimetric analysis, element analysis and single-crystal structures, respectively. The high R factor for FIR-53-Cr 2 O 7 may be related to the disordered guests. Crystal data for FIR-53: monoclinic, a = 34.4789(9) Å, b = 29.8973(6) Å, c = 16.2075(4) Å, β = 109.005(2)°, V = 15796.4(7) Å3, T = 100(2) K, space group C2/c, Z = 8, 31 457 reflections measured, 16 150 independent reflections (R int = 0.0344). The final R 1 value was 0.0464 (I > 2σ­(I)). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.1353 (I > 2σ­(I)). The final R 1 value was 0.0591 (all data). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.1441 (all data). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.056. Crystal data for FIR-54: orthorhombic, a = 28.4095(12) Å, b = 28.0922(11) Å, c = 9.4743(5) Å, V = 7561.3(6) Å3, T = 100(2) K, space group Pnna, Z = 8, 18 175 reflections measured, 7761 independent reflections (R int = 0.0512). The final R 1 value was 0.0805 (I > 2σ­(I)). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.2377 (I > 2σ­(I)). The final R 1 value was 0.1057 (all data). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.2657 (all data). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.003. Crystal data for FIR-53-Cr 2 O 7 : monoclinic, a = 35.157(8) Å, b = 29.716(6) Å, c = 16.278(4) Å, β = 109.757(4)°, V = 16005(6) Å3, T = 100(2) K, space group C2/c, Z = 8, 63 658 reflections measured, 18 329 independent reflections (R int = 0.0745). The final R 1 value was 0.1085 (I > 2σ­(I)). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.3157 (I > 2σ­(I)). The final R 1 value was 0.1286 (all data). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.3348 (all data). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.175.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Studies

Suitable single crystals were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Whereafter, single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses were performed on a computer-controlled SuperNova CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λMo-Kα = 0.71073 Å) and Cu Kα radiation (λCu-Kα = 1.54178 Å). The structures were solved using the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 by using the SHELX-97 program package. The SQUEEZE option of PLATON was used to eliminate the contribution of disordered guest molecules to the reflection intensities. The formulas of FIR-53 and FIR-54 were calculated by considering the results of thermogravimetric analysis, element analysis and single-crystal structures, respectively. The high R factor for FIR-53-Cr  2  O  7  may be related to the disordered guests. Crystal data for FIR-53: monoclinic, a = 34.4789(9) Å, b = 29.8973(6) Å, c = 16.2075(4) Å, β = 109.005(2)°, V = 15796.4(7) Å3, T = 100(2) K, space group C2/c, Z = 8, 31457 reflections measured, 16150 independent reflections (R int = 0.0344). The final R 1 value was 0.0464 (I > 2σ(I)). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.1353 (I > 2σ(I)). The final R 1 value was 0.0591 (all data). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.1441 (all data). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.056. Crystal data for FIR-54: orthorhombic, a = 28.4095(12) Å, b = 28.0922(11) Å, c = 9.4743(5) Å, V = 7561.3(6) Å3, T = 100(2) K, space group Pnna, Z = 8, 18175 reflections measured, 7761 independent reflections (R int = 0.0512). The final R 1 value was 0.0805 (I > 2σ(I)). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.2377 (I > 2σ(I)). The final R 1 value was 0.1057 (all data). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.2657 (all data). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.003. Crystal data for FIR-53-Cr  2  O  7 : monoclinic, a = 35.157(8) Å, b = 29.716(6) Å, c = 16.278(4) Å, β = 109.757(4)°, V = 16005(6) Å3, T = 100(2) K, space group C2/c, Z = 8, 63658 reflections measured, 18329 independent reflections (R  int  = 0.0745). The final R 1 value was 0.1085 (I > 2σ(I)). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.3157 (I > 2σ(I)). The final R 1 value was 0.1286 (all data). The final wR(F 2) value was 0.3348 (all data). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.175.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray crystallography reveals that compound FIR-53 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c and features a double-(6,3)-layer structure. As shown in Figure a, in the structure of FIR-53, each Zn­(II) center shows tetrahedral geometry and is coordinated by three N atoms from three Tipa ligands and one O atom from the μ2-OH group. Without the μ2-OH groups, the μ3-Tipa ligands link the Zn­(II) centers into a (6,3)-layer along the ab plane. Two (6,3)-layers are further connected together by the μ2-OH groups to form a double layer (Figure b), and the resulting double layers are packing into a three-dimensional cationic [Zn2(Tipa)2­(OH)]3+ framework with π–π interactions (3.850 Å, the distance between the centers of benzene rings) between adjacent layers. The overall [Zn2(Tipa)2­(OH)]3+ framework shows 1D ellipse channels along the c axis (Figure c), and the window size for each channel is approximately 18 × 13 Å2 (taking the van der Waals radii into consideration). Although a large number of cationic MOFs have been reported, to the best of our knowledge, cationic MOFs with so large nanotubular channels are very rare. Remarkably, two structurally ordered NO3 – anions are presented in the asymmetric unit of FIR-53, and the third NO3 – anion is disordered in the structure. The contribution of the disordered solvent molecules and NO3 – anions was subtracted from the reflection data by the SQUEEZE method as implemented in PLATON program, and a total of 41.6% of the accessible volume for FIR-53 was found.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Single-crystal X-ray crystallography reveals that compound FIR-53 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c and features a double-(6,3)-layer structure. As shown in Figure a, in the structure of FIR-53, each Zn(II) center shows tetrahedral geometry and is coordinated by three N atoms from three Tipa ligands and one O atom from the μ2-OH group. Without the μ2-OH groups, the μ3-Tipa ligands link the Zn(II) centers into a (6,3)-layer along the ab plane. Two (6,3)-layers are further connected together by the μ2-OH groups to form a double layer (Figure b), and the resulting double layers are packing into a three-dimensional cationic [Zn2(Tipa)2(OH)]3+ framework with π-π interactions (3.850 Å, the distance between the centers of benzene rings) between adjacent layers. The overall [Zn2(Tipa)2(OH)]3+ framework shows 1D ellipse channels along the c axis (Figure c), and the window size for each channel is approximately 18 × 13 Å2 (taking the van der Waals radii into consideration). Although a large number of cationic MOFs have been reported, to the best of our knowledge, cationic MOFs with so large nanotubular channels are very rare. Remarkably, two structurally ordered NO3 - anions are presented in the asymmetric unit of FIR-53, and the third NO3 - anion is disordered in the structure. The contribution of the disordered solvent molecules and NO3 - anions was subtracted from the reflection data by the SQUEEZE method as implemented in PLATON program, and a total of 41.6% of the accessible volume for FIR-53 was found.

elements.content: (a) The coordination environment in FIR-53. (b) The double-layer in FIR-53. (c) The open framework with large channels in FIR-53.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The coordination environment in FIR-53. (b) The double-layer in FIR-53. (c) The open framework with large channels in FIR-53.

elements.content: Unlike FIR-53, FIR-54 crystallizes in space group Pnna and exhibits a 3D open framework with 1D helix channels. In the structure of FIR-54, each Zn­(II) center is tetrahedrally coordinated by three N atoms from three Tipa ligands and one O atom from the coordinated water molecule (Figure a). The μ3-Tipa ligands connect the Zn­(II) centers into a cationic 3D framework with 3-connected utp topology (Figure S2 in the ). Notably, the Zn–Tipa connectivity generates equal right- and left-handed hexagonal helices in the network (Figure b). The 2-fold interpenetrating final framework still shows 1D channels with the 10.5 Å × 10.5 Å windows (Figure c). Given the charge-balance consideration, there are two NO3 – ions per formula unit. However, the disordered ions and guest molecules are not well-defined. The effective free volume per unit cell volume, calculated by PLATON analyses, is 41.8% (3163.1 Å3 per unit) without consideration of the guest molecules and NO3 – anions.
elements.clean_text: Unlike FIR-53, FIR-54 crystallizes in space group Pnna and exhibits a 3D open framework with 1D helix channels. In the structure of FIR-54, each Zn(II) center is tetrahedrally coordinated by three N atoms from three Tipa ligands and one O atom from the coordinated water molecule (Figure a). The μ3-Tipa ligands connect the Zn(II) centers into a cationic 3D framework with 3-connected utp topology (Figure S2 in the ). Notably, the Zn-Tipa connectivity generates equal right- and left-handed hexagonal helices in the network (Figure b). The 2-fold interpenetrating final framework still shows 1D channels with the 10.5 Å × 10.5 Å windows (Figure c). Given the charge-balance consideration, there are two NO3 - ions per formula unit. However, the disordered ions and guest molecules are not well-defined. The effective free volume per unit cell volume, calculated by PLATON analyses, is 41.8% (3163.1 Å3 per unit) without consideration of the guest molecules and NO3 - anions.

elements.content: (a) The asymmetric coordination unit in FIR-54. (b) The 3D framework consists of the alternately arranged right- and left-handed hexagonal helices. (c) 2-fold interpenetrating structure with large channels.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) The asymmetric coordination unit in FIR-54. (b) The 3D framework consists of the alternately arranged right- and left-handed hexagonal helices. (c) 2-fold interpenetrating structure with large channels.

elements.content: Given that FIR-53 is a highly charged cationic layer structure, anion exchange for oxo-anion pollutants was studied and chromate was chosen as an initial model. The anion exchange was performed under ambient conditions by simply placing crystals of FIR-53 into the dichromate solution with 2 × 10–3 mol/L. The vials keep static after introducing 60 mg of dried FIR-53 into a 4 mL dichromate aqueous solution. (The molar ratio between FIR-53 and dichromate is about 1:2.) The resultant exchange solution was monitored by liquid UV–vis spectroscopy at intervals. The intensity of the main characteristic adsorption peak of Cr2O7 2– (257 nm) quickly decreased at the early stage, indicating that the Cr2O7 2– in solution promptly entered into the channels in FIR-53 by exchanging NO3 –. As shown in Figure b, FIR-53 was submerged in 2 × 10–3 mol/L aqueous solution of K2Cr2O7, and the corresponding Cr2O7 2– concentration in solution decreased by 95% within only 10 min. No further decrease in dichromate concentration was detected after 1 h, indicating that the anion-exchange process was complete. Meanwhile, the color of the solid in the solution changed from colorless to yellow (Figure a), implying the existence of Cr2O7 2– in the solid. Noteworthily, single crystals retain their integrity throughout the exchange.
elements.clean_text: Given that FIR-53 is a highly charged cationic layer structure, anion exchange for oxo-anion pollutants was studied and chromate was chosen as an initial model. The anion exchange was performed under ambient conditions by simply placing crystals of FIR-53 into the dichromate solution with 2 × 10-3 mol/L. The vials keep static after introducing 60 mg of dried FIR-53 into a 4 mL dichromate aqueous solution. (The molar ratio between FIR-53 and dichromate is about 1:2.) The resultant exchange solution was monitored by liquid UV-vis spectroscopy at intervals. The intensity of the main characteristic adsorption peak of Cr2O7 2- (257 nm) quickly decreased at the early stage, indicating that the Cr2O7 2- in solution promptly entered into the channels in FIR-53 by exchanging NO3 -. As shown in Figure b, FIR-53 was submerged in 2 × 10-3 mol/L aqueous solution of K2Cr2O7, and the corresponding Cr2O7 2- concentration in solution decreased by 95% within only 10 min. No further decrease in dichromate concentration was detected after 1 h, indicating that the anion-exchange process was complete. Meanwhile, the color of the solid in the solution changed from colorless to yellow (Figure a), implying the existence of Cr2O7 2- in the solid. Noteworthily, single crystals retain their integrity throughout the exchange.

elements.content: (a) Color change of FIR-53 crystals before and after ion exchange. (b) Adsorption kinetics of Cr­(VI) at different concentrations (2 × 10–3, 4 × 10–3, 6 × 10–3 mol/L) for FIR-53.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Color change of FIR-53 crystals before and after ion exchange. (b) Adsorption kinetics of Cr(VI) at different concentrations (2 × 10-3, 4 × 10-3, 6 × 10-3 mol/L) for FIR-53.

elements.content: Similar ion-exchange experiments on FIR-53 were further carried out in 4 × 10–3 and 6 × 10–3 mol/L solutions of K2Cr2O7, and 93.3% and 73.4% of the dichromate in the solution were uptaken by FIR-53 after 4 h, respectively. Subsequently, a slow decrease in Cr2O7 2– concentration was observed, and no further decrease in anion concentration was detected after 10 and 18 h. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) and UV–vis spectroscopy indicated that nearly 100% and 90% Cr2O7 2– were trapped into the channel of FIR-53 in 4 × 10–3 and 6 × 10–3 mol/L solutions of K2Cr2O7, respectively (Figure b). The total exchange capacity of FIR-53 for dichromate is 74.2 mg/g (the theoretically maximum dichromate capacity is 217.6 mg/g). In addition, the same experiments were carried out for FIR-54, and the similar adsorption trends were discovered as well as FIR-53 (Figures S4 and S5 in the ). The overall adsorption capacity of FIR-54 for dichromate reaches up to 103 mg/g (Figure S7 in the ) (the theoretically maximum dichromate capacity is 278.4 mg/g). It is worth mentioning that only limited cases have been reported of the exchange of Cr2O7 2– by cationic crystalline materials. For examples, 2-D compound, SLUG-21, exhibited 60 mg/g exchange capacity for Cr2O7 2– after exchanging for 48 h, and 3-D Dy-based MOFs can capture 62.9 mg/g in 6 h. The adsorption capacity of natural zeolites modified with hexadecylpyridinium bromide is 14.3 mg/g after 48 h (Table S1 in the ). Comparably, FIR-53 and FIR-54 exhibit high-capacity and high-efficient trapping of Cr2O7 2–.
elements.clean_text: Similar ion-exchange experiments on FIR-53 were further carried out in 4 × 10-3 and 6 × 10-3 mol/L solutions of K2Cr2O7, and 93.3% and 73.4% of the dichromate in the solution were uptaken by FIR-53 after 4 h, respectively. Subsequently, a slow decrease in Cr2O7 2- concentration was observed, and no further decrease in anion concentration was detected after 10 and 18 h. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) and UV-vis spectroscopy indicated that nearly 100% and 90% Cr2O7 2- were trapped into the channel of FIR-53 in 4 × 10-3 and 6 × 10-3 mol/L solutions of K2Cr2O7, respectively (Figure b). The total exchange capacity of FIR-53 for dichromate is 74.2 mg/g (the theoretically maximum dichromate capacity is 217.6 mg/g). In addition, the same experiments were carried out for FIR-54, and the similar adsorption trends were discovered as well as FIR-53 (Figures S4 and S5 in the ). The overall adsorption capacity of FIR-54 for dichromate reaches up to 103 mg/g (Figure S7 in the ) (the theoretically maximum dichromate capacity is 278.4 mg/g). It is worth mentioning that only limited cases have been reported of the exchange of Cr2O7 2- by cationic crystalline materials. For examples, 2-D compound, SLUG-21, exhibited 60 mg/g exchange capacity for Cr2O7 2- after exchanging for 48 h, and 3-D Dy-based MOFs can capture 62.9 mg/g in 6 h. The adsorption capacity of natural zeolites modified with hexadecylpyridinium bromide is 14.3 mg/g after 48 h (Table S1 in the ). Comparably, FIR-53 and FIR-54 exhibit high-capacity and high-efficient trapping of Cr2O7 2-.

elements.content: The release tests were carried out to evaluate the regeneration ability of the ion exchanger. For FIR-53, the samples were centrifuged, rinsed with water, and dried in air after being submerged in 2 × 10–3 mol/L dichromate solution for 3 days; then the solid was placed in the same volume solution in the presence of a 200-fold molar excess of nitrate. The UV–Vis measurement showed that the release efficiency of Cr2O7 2– was high up to 98% after 26 h (Figure a). Such a trapping and releasing process was performed for five continuous cycles; FIR-53 still retains approximately 87% release efficiency (Figure b). Generally, the release of the pollutant anions is more difficult due to the strong interactions between metal oxo anions and cationic framework. For example, SLUG-21 has the ability of rapid capture, but reuse of the material is in fact undesirable. By contrast, FIR-53 displays much faster and more effective in the trapping–releasing processes.
elements.clean_text: The release tests were carried out to evaluate the regeneration ability of the ion exchanger. For FIR-53, the samples were centrifuged, rinsed with water, and dried in air after being submerged in 2 × 10-3 mol/L dichromate solution for 3 days; then the solid was placed in the same volume solution in the presence of a 200-fold molar excess of nitrate. The UV-Vis measurement showed that the release efficiency of Cr2O7 2- was high up to 98% after 26 h (Figure a). Such a trapping and releasing process was performed for five continuous cycles; FIR-53 still retains approximately 87% release efficiency (Figure b). Generally, the release of the pollutant anions is more difficult due to the strong interactions between metal oxo anions and cationic framework. For example, SLUG-21 has the ability of rapid capture, but reuse of the material is in fact undesirable. By contrast, FIR-53 displays much faster and more effective in the trapping-releasing processes.

elements.content: (a) The full trapping–releasing process of ion exchange for FIR-53 in a complete cycle. The photographs show the color of crystals before and after trapping–releasing process. (b) The exchanged ratio (green pillars) and released ratio (gray pillars) of Cr2O7 2– ions during five times reuse cycles.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) The full trapping-releasing process of ion exchange for FIR-53 in a complete cycle. The photographs show the color of crystals before and after trapping-releasing process. (b) The exchanged ratio (green pillars) and released ratio (gray pillars) of Cr2O7 2- ions during five times reuse cycles.

elements.content: The reversibility of FIR-54 was also tested. Unlike FIR-53, there was almost no dichromate to be released in the 200-fold molar excess of nitrate solution. When 200-fold molar amounts of SO4 2– or ClO4 – were used as the triggers, 27% and 91% of Cr2O7 2– were exchanged after 72 h, respectively. No further release was detected. In Na2ClO4 solution, the exchange efficiency dropped to 63% after five trapping–releasing cycles (Figure S6 in the ).
elements.clean_text: The reversibility of FIR-54 was also tested. Unlike FIR-53, there was almost no dichromate to be released in the 200-fold molar excess of nitrate solution. When 200-fold molar amounts of SO4 2- or ClO4 - were used as the triggers, 27% and 91% of Cr2O7 2- were exchanged after 72 h, respectively. No further release was detected. In Na2ClO4 solution, the exchange efficiency dropped to 63% after five trapping-releasing cycles (Figure S6 in the ).

elements.content: Equally important to capacity for anion trapping is selectivity. Given the high-capacity and rapid ion-exchange function of FIR-53, the selective adsorption was verified. The dried FIR-53 sample (120 mg) was immersed in a 10 mL solution containing mixed anions (Cl–, Br–, NO3 –, Cr2O7 2–), with 0.01 mol/L of each, for 48 h. The UV–vis and ICP measurements indicated that the adsorption of Cr2O7 2– is not disturbed by other ions. Nevertheless, when the equal molar CO3 2– was added in the above solution, the uptake efficiency of Cr2O7 2– went down sharply to 17% or so, indicating that the CO3 2– ion is the strong competitor to Cr2O7 2– ion (Figure S8 in the ). When the dried FIR-53 sample was immersed in a 10 mL solution containing mixed anions (Cl–, Br–, NO3 – with a concentration of 0.10 mol/L or 0.40 mol/L, and Cr2O7 2– with a concentration of 0.01 mol/L) for 48 h, the adsorption of Cr2O7 2– was still at high efficiency. Once more, when the dried FIR-53 sample was immersed in the mixed solution (Cl–, Br–, NO3 –, SO4 2–, ClO4 – with a concentration of 0.10 mol/L of each, and Cr2O7 2– with a concentration of 0.01 mol/L), the ion-exchange efficiency of Cr2O7 2– drastically dropped (Figure S9 in the ).
elements.clean_text: Equally important to capacity for anion trapping is selectivity. Given the high-capacity and rapid ion-exchange function of FIR-53, the selective adsorption was verified. The dried FIR-53 sample (120 mg) was immersed in a 10 mL solution containing mixed anions (Cl-, Br-, NO3 -, Cr2O7 2-), with 0.01 mol/L of each, for 48 h. The UV-vis and ICP measurements indicated that the adsorption of Cr2O7 2- is not disturbed by other ions. Nevertheless, when the equal molar CO3 2- was added in the above solution, the uptake efficiency of Cr2O7 2- went down sharply to 17% or so, indicating that the CO3 2- ion is the strong competitor to Cr2O7 2- ion (Figure S8 in the ). When the dried FIR-53 sample was immersed in a 10 mL solution containing mixed anions (Cl-, Br-, NO3 - with a concentration of 0.10 mol/L or 0.40 mol/L, and Cr2O7 2- with a concentration of 0.01 mol/L) for 48 h, the adsorption of Cr2O7 2- was still at high efficiency. Once more, when the dried FIR-53 sample was immersed in the mixed solution (Cl-, Br-, NO3 -, SO4 2-, ClO4 - with a concentration of 0.10 mol/L of each, and Cr2O7 2- with a concentration of 0.01 mol/L), the ion-exchange efficiency of Cr2O7 2- drastically dropped (Figure S9 in the ).

elements.content: UV–vis and ICP analyses revealed the existence and molar amount of Cr­(VI). Meanwhile, the appearance of an IR characteristic adsorption coming from Cr2O7 2– at about 770 cm–1 and the disappearance of the broad band arising from NO3 – at 1350 cm–1 were observed, also suggesting that Cr2O7 2– replaced NO3 – into the channel of FIR-53 or FIR-54 (Figures S13 and S14 in the ). However, these characterization methods cannot supply a direct and accurate picture to show the structure containing the dichromate. Fortunately, the sample FIR-53 (or FIR-54) after ion exchange was subject to single-crystal X-ray diffraction, but only the structure of FIR-53 containing the guest anions was obtained. As shown in Figure , Cr2O7 2– anions fill into the channels to balance the framework charge, indicating that ion exchange occurred exactly via single-crystal-to- single-crystal transformation. It is also observed that Cr2O7 2– anions like NO3 – anions are fixed into the double layer, and adjoin the edge of the large channel (Figure c,d). Moreover, weak C–H···O interactions between the framework and Cr2O7 2– anions were found (Table S2 in the ). The phenomenon indicates that the anions can be easily exchanged, which need to go over very little resistance, and the large channel provides a fairly convenient passage for the diffusion of anions. These results can well explain that FIR-53 has the ability of the high-efficient ion exchange and excellent reversibility. More valuably, it demonstrates that the above adsorption capacity of Cr­(VI) is correct through dichromate identified as the principal component.
elements.clean_text: UV-vis and ICP analyses revealed the existence and molar amount of Cr(VI). Meanwhile, the appearance of an IR characteristic adsorption coming from Cr2O7 2- at about 770 cm-1 and the disappearance of the broad band arising from NO3 - at 1350 cm-1 were observed, also suggesting that Cr2O7 2- replaced NO3 - into the channel of FIR-53 or FIR-54 (Figures S13 and S14 in the ). However, these characterization methods cannot supply a direct and accurate picture to show the structure containing the dichromate. Fortunately, the sample FIR-53 (or FIR-54) after ion exchange was subject to single-crystal X-ray diffraction, but only the structure of FIR-53 containing the guest anions was obtained. As shown in Figure , Cr2O7 2- anions fill into the channels to balance the framework charge, indicating that ion exchange occurred exactly via single-crystal-to- single-crystal transformation. It is also observed that Cr2O7 2- anions like NO3 - anions are fixed into the double layer, and adjoin the edge of the large channel (Figure c,d). Moreover, weak C-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions between the framework and Cr2O7 2- anions were found (Table S2 in the ). The phenomenon indicates that the anions can be easily exchanged, which need to go over very little resistance, and the large channel provides a fairly convenient passage for the diffusion of anions. These results can well explain that FIR-53 has the ability of the high-efficient ion exchange and excellent reversibility. More valuably, it demonstrates that the above adsorption capacity of Cr(VI) is correct through dichromate identified as the principal component.

elements.content: Structures of FIR-53 before and after ion exchange: (a) 3D structure of FIR-53 containing NO3 – along the c axis; (b) 3D structure of FIR-53 containing NO3 – along the b axis; (c) 3D structure of FIR-53 containing Cr2O7 2– along the c axis; (d) 3D structure of FIR-53 containing Cr2O7 2– along the b axis.
elements.clean_text: 5  Structures of FIR-53 before and after ion exchange: (a) 3D structure of FIR-53 containing NO3 - along the c axis; (b) 3D structure of FIR-53 containing NO3 - along the b axis; (c) 3D structure of FIR-53 containing Cr2O7 2- along the c axis; (d) 3D structure of FIR-53 containing Cr2O7 2- along the b axis.

elements.content: In summary, two cationic MOFs (FIR-53 and FIR-54) consisting of nanotubular channels have been successfully prepared through the assembly of Zn2+ ions and neutral Tipa ligands. The large-scale channels of the frameworks of FIR-53 and FIR-54 provide a very convenient pathway for the diffusion capture of dichromate. FIR-54 has a high adsorption capacity for dichromate with an uptake value over 100 mg g–1. Particularly, FIR-53 and FIR-54 can trap Cr2O7 2– through SC-SC transformation with high capacity. It is worth mentioning that FIR-53 shows excellent reversibility and regeneration without losing its uptake capacity. The accurate structure after ionic exchange can be obtained via the mean of single-crystal X-ray diffraction, demonstrating that chromium Cr­(VI) ion exists in the form of dichromate. This work provides an effective strategy for the design of the ion-exchange media by employing cationic MOFs with large channels, and will contribute a lot to the removal of toxic heavy-metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, two cationic MOFs (FIR-53 and FIR-54) consisting of nanotubular channels have been successfully prepared through the assembly of Zn2+ ions and neutral Tipa ligands. The large-scale channels of the frameworks of FIR-53 and FIR-54 provide a very convenient pathway for the diffusion capture of dichromate. FIR-54 has a high adsorption capacity for dichromate with an uptake value over 100 mg g-1. Particularly, FIR-53 and FIR-54 can trap Cr2O7 2- through SC-SC transformation with high capacity. It is worth mentioning that FIR-53 shows excellent reversibility and regeneration without losing its uptake capacity. The accurate structure after ionic exchange can be obtained via the mean of single-crystal X-ray diffraction, demonstrating that chromium Cr(VI) ion exists in the form of dichromate. This work provides an effective strategy for the design of the ion-exchange media by employing cationic MOFs with large channels, and will contribute a lot to the removal of toxic heavy-metal ions.

elements.content: Experimental details, additional FTIR, TGA, and PXRD for solids before and after anion exchange, UV–vis absorption spectra monitored for dichromate exchange, additional figures, and CIF files (CCDC-1026824–1026826). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Experimental details, additional FTIR, TGA, and PXRD for solids before and after anion exchange, UV-vis absorption spectra monitored for dichromate exchange, additional figures, and CIF files (CCDC-1026824-1026826). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
Tris­(4-bromo­phenyl)­amine (0.480 g, 1.0 mmol), imidazole (0.41 g, 6.0 mmol), K2CO3 (0.728 g, 6.0 mmol), and CuSO4 (0.01 g, 0.04 mmol) were mixed and heated at 120 °C for 48 h under a nitrogen atmosphere. The mixture was cooled to the room temperature, and was then washed with water. The solids were filtered and dried to give the light pale crude product. Final Tipa sample was recrystallized from this light pale crude product by using water and ethanol as solvent (Yield: 74%).

Synthesis of <bold>FIR-53</bold>

A mixture of Tipa (0.0225 g, 0.05 mmol), l-proline (0.0115 g, 0.10 mmol), Zn­(NO3)2·​6H2O (0.0560 g, 0.2 mmol), MeOH (8 mL), and NaOH (2 mL, 0.1 M) was heated in a 20 mL scintillation vial at 100 °C for 72 h, followed by cooling to room temperature. The resulting mixture was washed with methanol and water, and colorless block crystals were collected and dried in air (29.2 mg, 73% yield, based on Tipa ligand).

Synthesis of <bold>FIR-54</bold>

A mixture of Tipa (0.0225 g, 0.05 mmol), l-proline (0.0115 g, 0.10 mmol), Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0560 g, 0.2 mmol), and DMF/MeOH/H2O (5 mL, v:v:v 3:1:1) was placed in a 20 mL scintillation vial at 100 °C for 12 h, followed by cooling to room temperature. The resulting mixture was washed with DMF and water, and colorless block crystals were collected and dried in air (38.4 mg, 64% yield, based on Tipa ligand).

Synthesis of <bold>FIR-53-Cr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> </bold>

The crystals of as-synthesized FIR-53 (60 mg, 0.05 mmol) were immersed in a 20 mL 2 × 10–3 mol/L solution of K2Cr2O7 and kept for 6 days. After decanting the solution, the resultant orange-yellow crystals were washed thoroughly with deionized water and dried in air.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Tris(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)phenyl)amine (Tipa; Scheme )

Tris(4-bromophenyl)amine (0.480 g, 1.0 mmol), imidazole (0.41 g, 6.0 mmol), K2CO3 (0.728 g, 6.0 mmol), and CuSO4 (0.01 g, 0.04 mmol) were mixed and heated at 120 °C for 48 h under a nitrogen atmosphere. The mixture was cooled to the room temperature, and was then washed with water. The solids were filtered and dried to give the light pale crude product. Final Tipa sample was recrystallized from this light pale crude product by using water and ethanol as solvent (Yield: 74%).

Synthesis of FIR-53 

A mixture of Tipa (0.0225 g, 0.05 mmol), l-proline (0.0115 g, 0.10 mmol), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0560 g, 0.2 mmol), MeOH (8 mL), and NaOH (2 mL, 0.1 M) was heated in a 20 mL scintillation vial at 100 °C for 72 h, followed by cooling to room temperature. The resulting mixture was washed with methanol and water, and colorless block crystals were collected and dried in air (29.2 mg, 73% yield, based on Tipa ligand).

Synthesis of FIR-54 

A mixture of Tipa (0.0225 g, 0.05 mmol), l-proline (0.0115 g, 0.10 mmol), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0560 g, 0.2 mmol), and DMF/MeOH/H2O (5 mL, v:v:v 3:1:1) was placed in a 20 mL scintillation vial at 100 °C for 12 h, followed by cooling to room temperature. The resulting mixture was washed with DMF and water, and colorless block crystals were collected and dried in air (38.4 mg, 64% yield, based on Tipa ligand).

Synthesis of FIR-53-Cr2O7  

The crystals of as-synthesized FIR-53 (60 mg, 0.05 mmol) were immersed in a 20 mL 2 × 10-3 mol/L solution of K2Cr2O7 and kept for 6 days. After decanting the solution, the resultant orange-yellow crystals were washed thoroughly with deionized water and dried in air.

cln_elements.content: Unlike FIR-53, FIR-54 crystallizes in space group Pnna and exhibits a 3D open framework with 1D helix channels. In the structure of FIR-54, each Zn­(II) center is tetrahedrally coordinated by three N atoms from three Tipa ligands and one O atom from the coordinated water molecule (Figure a). The μ3-Tipa ligands connect the Zn­(II) centers into a cationic 3D framework with 3-connected utp topology (Figure S2 in the ). Notably, the Zn–Tipa connectivity generates equal right- and left-handed hexagonal helices in the network (Figure b). The 2-fold interpenetrating final framework still shows 1D channels with the 10.5 Å × 10.5 Å windows (Figure c). Given the charge-balance consideration, there are two NO3 – ions per formula unit. However, the disordered ions and guest molecules are not well-defined. The effective free volume per unit cell volume, calculated by PLATON analyses, is 41.8% (3163.1 Å3 per unit) without consideration of the guest molecules and NO3 – anions.
cln_elements.clean_text: Unlike FIR-53, FIR-54 crystallizes in space group Pnna and exhibits a 3D open framework with 1D helix channels. In the structure of FIR-54, each Zn(II) center is tetrahedrally coordinated by three N atoms from three Tipa ligands and one O atom from the coordinated water molecule (Figure a). The μ3-Tipa ligands connect the Zn(II) centers into a cationic 3D framework with 3-connected utp topology (Figure S2 in the ). Notably, the Zn-Tipa connectivity generates equal right- and left-handed hexagonal helices in the network (Figure b). The 2-fold interpenetrating final framework still shows 1D channels with the 10.5 Å × 10.5 Å windows (Figure c). Given the charge-balance consideration, there are two NO3 - ions per formula unit. However, the disordered ions and guest molecules are not well-defined. The effective free volume per unit cell volume, calculated by PLATON analyses, is 41.8% (3163.1 Å3 per unit) without consideration of the guest molecules and NO3 - anions.

metadata.title:
Water-Stable Metal–Organic Frameworks for Fast
and High Dichromate Trapping via Single-Crystal-to-Single-Crystal
Ion Exchange
